dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And the WHO, uh, they've actually developed this new tool called AWaRe to, you know, try and tackle it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It classifies antibiotics into three groups: Access, Watch, and Reserve. It's all about making antibiotic use safer, and, um, more effective.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It classifies antibiotics into three groups: Access, Watch, and Reserve. It's all about making antibiotic use safer, and, um, more effective.

dialogue_turns.text: So, like, guiding doctors on *which* antibiotic to use? Or when?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, guiding doctors on which antibiotic to use? Or when?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely! The big push is to get at least 60% of global consumption into the 'Access' group. These are narrow-spectrum antibiotics, so they're less likely to cause resistance, and um, often cheaper too.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The new campaign aims to increase the proportion of global consumption of antibiotics in the Access group to at least 60%... Using Access antibiotics lowers the risk of resistance because they are narrow-spectrum antibiotics (that target a specific microorganism rather than several). They are also less costly because they are available in generic formulations.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Antimicrobial resistance is one of the most urgent health risks of our time and threatens to undo a century of medical progress, said Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, WHO Director-General.

dialogue_turns.text: And it's not just about the effectiveness, is it? I mean, when antibiotics stop working, it means more expensive treatments, longer hospital stays. And, um, a huge burden on healthcare budgets.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When antibiotics stop working effectively, more expensive treatments and hospital admissions are needed, taking a heavy toll on already stretched health budgets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And ironically, in low-income countries, there are still huge gaps in *access* to even basic, effective antibiotics, leading to, like, childhood deaths from pneumonia.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the same time, many low- and middle-income countries experience vast gaps in access to effective and appropriate antibiotics. Childhood deaths due to pneumonia (estimated globally at close to one million per year) because of lack of access to antibiotics remain frequent in many parts of the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's this crazy balance, right? Ensuring people get life-saving drugs, but also making sure we don't overuse them and make them useless.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's this crazy balance, right? Ensuring people get life-saving drugs, but also making sure we don't overuse them and make them useless.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: All countries must strike a balance between ensuring access to life-saving antibiotics and slowing drug resistance by reserving the use of some antibiotics for the hardest-to-treat infections.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a tightrope. And that's where AWaRe really comes in – to guide policymakers and doctors. Because without new antibiotics, improving how we use the ones we have is, um, crucial.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a tightrope. And that's where A W a R e really comes in - to guide policymakers and doctors. Because without new antibiotics, improving how we use the ones we have is, um, crucial.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By classifying antibiotics into three distinct groups, and advising on when to use them, AWaRe makes it easier for policy-makers, prescribers and health workers to select the right antibiotic at the right time... In the absence of new significant investments into the development of new antibiotics, improving the use of antibiotics is one of the key actions needed to curb further emergence and spread of antimicrobial resistance.
